last_post.content: @moritz Oh no! I hope it's for bigger and better things. Their "Out of Sight, Out of Mind" drone strike #dataviz was profound and important. https://www.pitchinteractive.com/work/drones/

Check out Janine’s new paper on TMS multi-pulse I-wave independent short-interval intracortical facilitating in press in JNeurophysiol by Hartwig Siebner, Mitsuaki Takemi, Anke Karabanov and Lasse Christiansen.
https://doi.org/10.1152/jn.00263.2022

Kesselheim et al. find that delivering two or more pulses at interstimulus intervals corresponding to the peaks of individual SICF curves - but also the trough between the 1st and 2nd peak - facilitate MEPs and reduce corticomotor threshold.

TMS bursts facilitate corticomotor excitability via two mechanisms: SICF-dependently via fast-conducting direct projections from M1-HAND to spinal motoneurons and SICF–independently probably through slower conducting indirect pyramidal tract projections.

We argue that an exclusive focus on I-wave periodicity is too narrow when aiming at understanding how TMS excites the precentral motor representations. The role of the I-wave independent facilitation in the control and development of skilled movement deserves more attention.

#tms #SICF #motorcortex #M1 #I-waves #I-wave #neuro #neuroscience #newpaper #paperThread #researchpaper

Just out - a new systematic review of 42 studies on #learning effects of the #COVID19 #pandemic covering 15 countries by Bastian A. Betthäuser, @per and Anders Bach-Mortensen.

Substantial overall learning deficit which persists over time. Deficits are large for children from low SES and are larger in #math than in #reading, and in middle-income countries relative to high-income countries.

📢Join a team of linguists from USI Lugano, Basel University, University of Lausanne, and University of Neuchatel to work on #opendata in the study of #talkininteraction. Part-time assistant position, M.A. or PhD 🗓 04/2023-09/2024 📩Apply before February 15!

📋Call: https://content.usi.ch/sites/default/files/storage/attachments/ials/ials-call-assistant-project-chord-2023.pdf.

📋Project description:
The research assistant will contribute to the project “Data-sharing skills in corpus-based research on talk-in-interaction” short title: CHORD-Talk), which is part of the Open Research Data (ORD) program currently promoted by SwissUniversities and involves USI (leading house, coordinator: Johanna Miecznikowski) and the universities of Basel (Lorenza Mondada and Martin Luginbühl), Lausanne (Jérôme Jacquin) and Neuchâtel (Simona Pekarek). Audio-video recorded and transcribed corpora of spoken language in interaction are collected by a diversity of disciplines in the social sciences and the humanities. They are particularly complex and offer several challenges to ORD practices. The project aims at identifying the conditions that must be fulfilled in order to prepare and treat audio-video corpora of spoken language in interaction as ORD in a meaningful way. The project team members will analyse and assess existing ORD practices related to audio-video interactional data by reviewing the relevant literature, critically reflecting on their own practices, and organising workshops with international experts from leading data-hosting institutions. The team will explore possibilities to improve ORD practices, with a particular focus on researchers’ data-sharing skills and on the Swiss situation. It will engage with the concerned disciplines and communities, e.g. in the fields of interactional linguistics, conversation analysis and dialogue-oriented argumentation studies, and evaluate procedures to disseminate relevant knowledge in these communities in future.

from itertools import product

palette = (
'#817', '#a35', '#c66', '#e94',
'#ed0', '#9d5', '#4d8', '#2cb',
'#0bc', '#09c', '#36b', '#639'
)

def setup():
global palavras
size(800, 800)
no_loop()
rect_mode(CENTER)
no_stroke()

def draw():
w = 400
i = 0
for x, y in product(range(0, width, w), repeat=2):
for z in range(3):
fill(palette[i])
square(w / 2 + x, w / 2 + y, w / (z / 2 + 1))
i += 1

title: The Museum Built on Native American Burial Mounds

last_post.content:
Federal records show the Illinois State Museum holds the remains of at least 7,000 Native Americans. In three decades, it has returned only 2% of them — 156 individuals — to tribal nations who could claim them under the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act.

About 200 of them used to be on public display at one of the system’s museums and still haven’t been returned. Read the latest in The Repatriation Project.

title: A Quick Note on That Record Low Savings Rate

last_post.content: Silliness on saving rates -- quick comment. Many news stories have told us about our record low saving rates. As is widely noted, share buybacks are an alternative to dividends, if companies want to pay out money to shareholders.

P-value myths:

"p-value is the probability that your results occurred by chance"
"p-value is the probability that the null hypothesis is true" or the "false positive risk"

Actual definition: "p-value is the chance of seeing a difference at least as big as we have done, if, in fact, there were no real effect"

Stumbled across a neat sqlite-utils feature that I'd forgotten I had added: you can define custom SQL functions using a Python snippet passed to the --functions '...' option:

sqlite-utils content.db 'select up(title) from tutorials' --functions '
def up(s):
return s.upper()
' --table

up(title)
---------------------------------------------

This article is *excellent*. On its face it’s about #NYC #rent, but the larger story it tells is amazing — part ‘prosumer’-level data-science dive, part Alice in Wonderland. What the author finds is world of data that isn’t: cooked books, liars and shills, manipulated indicators, and a Bullshit-as-a-Service ( #BSaaS ) outfit that gives the landlord industry plausible deniability in the form of an “algorithm” to extort jaw-dropping amounts from renters across the US and around the world. Things like this make clear how much of the debate about #AI and #LLM is plain-old techno-fetishism or, as they say, *affirmative critique* — ‘lite’ analyses that end up endorsing what they supposedly question. It really doesn’t matter *how* the ‘data’ is generated — an AI, an intern putzing around with Excel, an army of typing monkeys. What matters is the power of an industry to create a Matrix-like illusion to rob the masses blind.
